Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Starting with data transformation, I have raw events with timestamps, action types, applications, and window titles. Each event is pretty low-level, like FOCUS, TYPING, SAVE, etc. I need to convert these into higher-level activities that make sense for process analysis.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at the log, I can see the user is switching between Microsoft Word, Google Chrome, and Adobe Acrobat. Each time they switch, it seems like theyre moving to a different task. For example, switching from Word to Chrome implies theyre checking email, then switching back to Word or Excel suggests theyre resuming their document work or budget updates.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: So, I think each time they start a new application or switch windows, its a new case. For instance, the first few events are all in Word, then they switch to Chrome, which is a new case, then back to Word, Excel, and so on. Each of these sequences represents a separate case.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: The raw actions like FOCUS, TYPING, SAVE, SWITCH, CLICK, etc., need to be translated into more descriptive names. For example, FOCUS in Word could be Editing Document, TYPING with specific keys could be Typing Text, SAVE is Saving Document, SWITCH between apps is Switching Applications, CLICK actions can become Clicking Action or more specific like Opening Email.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: I should aim for standardized names that capture the essence of the activity without being too granular. Maybe group similar actions together. For example, all typing actions can be Typing Text, and all save actions can be Saving Document.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: For event attributes, each event should have Case ID, Activity Name, Timestamp. I can also include the Application and Window Title as additional attributes for context. This will help in process analysis as analysts can see which applications and documents are involved in each case.
